pros: Holiday pay is the only pro to working in this department.
cons:
Unfair benefits for PRN status. Contribution to retirement is a requirement, but you have to work 750 hours per year for three years to be vested. I have been there three years but only have one year vested. No one can explain how those working hours are calculated, and I worked a lot and know I had to have met the minimum 750 hours per year. I called Fidelity as well as HR and got no help.

I have worked under two directors and two managers and never got a clear answer on how collection bonuses work for PRN. When hired I was told we just had to meet a formula for PRN collections each month and would receive a bonus as long as the department goal was met. Then both directors changed the rules and basically PRN have no chance at receiving a collection bonus. 

The current director is the worst director I have ever had in my 13 years of working healthcare. He makes you feel worthless and treats employees like garbage and makes it clear you are replaceable. He is very demeaning in all of his emails. He has absolutely no listening skills. During staff meetings he interrupts everyone.

Almost all of our department has left and full of new people due to the director's behavior, but nothing is done about it. 

Your opinion does not matter.

pros: There “were” some good people who worked here, but management has pushed most of them out the door. The pay is comparable to most other hospitals in the area.
cons: Poor management and favoritism. I have worked in the ER before and understand that this exists but its crazy on how bad it is here. The equal opportunity commission should audit this place and interview its employees. People who have worked here and years and have the skills to advance does not but only gets push out the door and others are just given the job without even applying for the position. Management has been caught saying they would rather run the whole department with travelers instead of staff. At least 60 percent are travelers 30 percent are band new with least 9 months of experience and the other 10 percent barely have ANY experience over 1 year and their feet is half way out the door already. Management do not care about retention or will they have your back when you need it. Within the last 6 months I have seen the mangers less then 5 times and thats me rounding up by 2 or 3 times. The environment is VERY hazardous. Nurses are attacked and verbally abuse and management does not even ask staff about the situation but try to sweep it under like nothing. I would NOT recommend this place for anyone except joint commission, equal opportunity commission, and OSHA.

pros: This review is about the Golden Cross Academic Clinic. Patient care provided is above average. Many resources available for the underserved community. Strong Residency program. Nursing staff encouraged to participate in this training. Salaries and benefits commensurate with experience and industry standards in the DFW metroplex. Physical environment very pleasant, well kept and clean.
cons: I was employed in the Methodist System for 19 years. In the final five years I noticed a disturbing trend of “encouraging” older or disabled employees to resign or retire early. This generally took the form of “write ups” on job performances of employees with impressive tenures. These were mostly critiques of performances that had been baseline for years. One couldn’t help but notice that each of these employees were either older or chronically ill. I personally retired eighteen months early as I could no longer witness this unethical behavior.

review_title: Being voted "Best Place to Work" doesn't make it so!
pros: There are some really great people and volunteers working there!!!  It's a hospital and primarily they are there to help people and that's a great thing.  The benefits are really good as long as you watch every move you make.
cons: Upper management was a mess when I was there.  There were so many mid to high level execs either resigning or getting fired you couldn't keep up.  The HR department totally mishandled my benefits and caused me to lose seven months of health insurance and gave me incorrect information related to short term disability that caused me to be disqualified for that benefit after I had to have surgery.  I was out of work for nine months with zero disability income due to their mistakes.   Also, based on my experience and job description, they pay EVERY low wages to employees with an extreme amount of responsibility for the accuracy and importance of patient orders and care.  This knowledge terrifies me every time I'm in a hospital and this last part seems to be industry wide.

review_title: MCMC FT critical care float - overall thumbs up

cons: Imbalance between Management vs staff. Micromanaging. Once I did cpr and saved a life.  Got an email about a tiny detail about charting before i even got home.  Need more positive feedback for staff that literally dont stop to eat or drink or pee throughout the shift. Yet there is lack of understanding from management.  Too many new staff members in ER/ICU.  ER is a disaster, but I think something is in the works to get it fixed because there are a lot of great nurses there. Also, IMC is a mess but they are working on it.

review_title: Best Place to Work and Provide Quality Healthcare
pros: Even though Methodist Dallas is a large hospital it has a small town feel. As you pass others in the hall they say hello. The staff is always willing to help visitors and other staff members when needed. Leadership is very supportive of staff and truly care about you as a person, They offer supportive benefits that show they care in addition to the regular benefits most employers offer. I have worked here for 21 years and I can't imagine working anywhere else.
cons: Everywhere you work will always have downsides and short comings, but at Methodist these are few and far between and very minor ones. I personally do not have any complaints about Methodist. They provide a shuttle from the parking areas during all weather conditions. The benefits are good, pay is comparable to other organizations, etc. In fact, almost everyone that leaves Methodist for "greener pastures" eventually returns to Methodist.

job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: An excellent team of doctors, staff, nurses, and medical assistants were collaborating and working for the benefit of others to save lives — the best job I have ever had.
cons: Some people did not want to do their job. There were too many interoffice changes working to make the office flow better when the flow worked quite well.

review_title: Very Toxic place proceed with caution!
pros: There are a lot of good people that work at MHS and believe in the mission. Oh and if you don't have a college degree you can get a great paying job as long as you know the right person!
cons: The CEO brings in his own team from another system he was with.  His daughter even works there! They set the worst leadership example from rudeness, to fear and intimidation, but they get away with it and always let you know how close they are to "Steve". Steve's latest minion got a job over someone that was being groomed for the position and had two masters degrees. The best candidate wasn't part of the inner circle or the correct ethnicity. If you know Steve you can be fired from a job and out of work for a year and one half and get job that should have went to the most qualified person.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Mansfield, TX
pros: Very good pay with bonuses for extra shifts (+$8); generally welcoming spirit in overall hospital; helpful orientation; make your own schedule.
cons: I worked on 5E the medical telemetry floor. It was always too busy and we were always understaffed and the nurses acted like they were too good to help the nurse aides. But they still wanted us to bathe all 12-18 patients we had, in addition to doing vitals every 4 hours AND hourly rounding. In addition to that, the management would ask you to complete stupid, inconsequential tasks like making sure empty rooms were stocked. Other than pay, they weren't making the overworking worth it. Many of the employees who've been there for years have left the hospital recently.

review_title: Came to an Organization that Thinks About the Long-Game
pros: Driven by a mission and focused on a simple Vision. This organization interviewed me for team fit as well as skills. Even though I did not qualify for a merit increase, Payroll conducted an unsolicited market analysis and gave my salary a bump up to be competitive. There are processes in place to prevent flavor-of-the-month initiatives from wasting company resources. Low turnover rates compared to industry benchmarks. Leadership development is a priority here, and the Emerging Leader Program is an amazing opportunity. Tuition reimbursement and the ADN nursing program through El Centro Community College still has me mindblown that my own immediate family or myself can become a Nurse paid for by MHS!
cons: Some systems and processes seem antiquated like the intranet and the telephony timekeeping, but they do amazing work with what they have and put their investments where it will benefit patients more  like Da Vinci surgical robots.

The doctors are nice but really only care about themselves. The EMR system is Epic and you will get very little training and expect to know it explicitly. No one knows what they’re doing and they can’t even hire people to answer the phones.

job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Dallas, TX
pros: Supportive management, great sense of belonging, cheap health benefits compered to other hospitals if you stay with Methodist providers.
cons: Frequent cancelling at times of low census making you use your vacation time. Employer does not offer free short term disability.  Health benefits are valued on your health risk factors, the more you have the more expensive. If you don't use Methodist providers, you end up paying hefty out pocket expenses. Chiropractor is not covered, despite knowing that most nurses have chronic back problems.

review_title: Best Place to Work with a Great Culture
pros: I'm still amazed at how the senior executives not only feel that patient care is a priority but also employee engagement. Employee engagement starts at the executive level and when staff feels valued, then they're job performance is top notch. I believe Methodist does a great job at this by recognizing staff at a system level and at each individual hospital. Every hospital has their own unique culture that creates a family-oriented environment. I come to work because I feel valued and because of my co-workers that I work with every day.  Methodist provides opportunities for career growth and is a learning environment.
cons: The technology could continue to improve more.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Dallas, TX
pros: I have worked here for going on 2 years and its been very rewarding. It is a trauma 1 hospital and there is always something new being presented that allows you to expand your knowledge. I feel appreciated and feel I am given opportunities to better myself in my career path.
cons: When I first started working here, there was a lot of scrutiny and politics. I was afraid it would be a short lived employment term. However once I proved myself, I feel right at home.

pros: The location is central and easy to get to. The Benefits are good and there is a clinic at the hospital that is free for employees.
cons:
I’ve worked at Methodist for a long time as an RN. During my time here, I can say that this is an okay Hospital to work for. Methodist recently started a diversity and inclusion program, but I’m afraid the the diversity isn’t seen on the executive level. The Hospital President sends out emails that are inappropriate in my opinion and sometimes have political undertones.

For example, he sent an email when Steve Scalise got shot but said nothing when the chaos in Charlottesville unraveled. I think his emails need to be vetted before sending them out to further consider how his employees will receive it.

During my time here, I’ve seen departments completely change. HR can’t ever keep the same staff and neither can the Benefits department. As soon as I get to know someone and trust them to help me they are gone. It makes me wonder what’s going on in there and makes me question if I can trust them with any issues I may have.

I’ve heard of several instances of racism and discrimination and have witnessed a fair share for myself. My African American co-workers are treated differently and unfairly. I get away with things that they don’t get away with. I often speak up and tell management but nothing happens. The Hospital isn’t blatantly racist but there is covert racism and discrimination in their practices. 

If you are a person of color, proceed with caution if you decide to work here. Read through some of the other reviews and you will see that several people have similar experiences. The Hospital looks great from the outside looking in, but once you get in you will experience something completely different.

pros: The administration and the management staff really are concerned for their employees.  The spiritual base of the organization helps to take care of patients in the spirit of Jesus Christ.  The professionalism of the staff is unmatched. The organization really pays attention to the staff and offers numerous ways to increase our education, our skill level and our desire to help our patient population.  A great access for the Oak Cliff area.
cons: It is hard to move up due to the high quality of the upper administrative staff already in place

review_title: BEWARE! Danger in the work place.
pros: This company lost (2) Vice Presidents within 7 months. One died of medical issues and the other left the company due to medical issues. Too much stress. Very High turnover for small company.
cons:
Small company, with several older people in key positions.  Company culture is straight out of 1950. 
 New energy is not welcome.  New ideas are not welcome. Proper protocol is not welcome.  Misery loves company, beware, danger, do not enter.  proceed to nearest EXIT!  Very high turnover for small company.

job_title: Diagnostic Medical Sonographer in Dallas, TX
pros: All team members fully support each other and are willing to jump in for anything.  Management is also supportive of team as well as patient goals.  We have enough management, but are not micromanaged.  Our talents are recognized and utilized.   The BEST thing about working at Methodist Dallas is how friendly both staff and patients are to everyone you see.  I've worked in places that mandate saying hello to people in the hall.  That mandate would never be necessary at MDMC.
cons: A private practice job would pay me a little more, but the sacrifice of the friendly and supportive culture isn't worth it to me.

pros: Great, mission-driven organization. Many, many, many committed caregivers.
cons: What an incredible hot mess of narcissistic, egotistical leadership:  Who: Steve Mansfield (portrays himself as a "Christian," but despises people of color (what happened to the mural, Steve?.) Demands to be addressed as "Dr." Mansfield. His PhD is from some second/third-tier university, and his thesis was re: hope. He takes more than $1M annually, despite the "Budget Pause." And he  proudly exclaims that Methodist is "below market" for talent. Yes, can we just say it's all about HIM?

review_title: Excellent Culture, Dedicated Team, Committed to the Mission

pros:
-Pay was very good for my position with options for bonuses. 
- My particular work area (& others I noticed) was laid back with no micro-managing from supervisors, only other employees. 
-Lots of benefit options. You can get very low cost health insurance and health care w/ lots of different services if you choose to use Methodist facilities. 
-My office also had flexible work hours and days off which made for a better work-life balance. 
-Positive mission and values of the company. Methodist has a cross on the logo and that definitely reflects the mission and values of the company, and that is what makes Methodist different from other hospitals.
cons:
-No company provided training at all. I was trained completely by my fellow coworkers, and inconsistently at that. Does not seem like a safe or smart business move considering this is HEALTHCARE. 
-No opportunities for advancement unless you can wait 10-15 years for someone to retire. 
-Very old fashioned, using outdated software and equipment. Healthcare today is cutting edge and this company is definitely behind the times. 
-Methodist spends little to no money on its employees, meaning that you will not get any new equipment until you absolutely have to have it. My office was using outdated computers that barely ran the software we used, & with tiny monitors and broken desks and office chairs. 
-There is no communication between upper management, supervisors, and employees. It seemed like no one knew what the rules and policies were until the right person did something wrong. 
-Lots of sticks in the mud. Employees who have worked there 10, 15, or 20+ years and are no longer productive employees, they just waiting for pay day. 
-As someone else mentioned, there is lots of soliciting from the company. They are always wanting you to donate this or contribute to that.

pros:
I have worked at Methodist Dallas for over 14 years in Critical Care. This is by far the best place to work as a nurse. The enviroment is family oriented and team oriented. The opportunities for advancement are endless! They have programs that help build leaders from within. Even though I have moved farther away from Dallas I still commute to work with the best team in the Metroplex. I've been able to advance my degree with their tuition reimbursement program
Tuition Reimbursement Program
Strive for excellence everyday
Employee Assistance Programs
Managers who care about there employees
cons: I don't have any cons to working here

pros: Methodist takes the time to develop employees by offering a myriad of different opportunities.  There are leadership programs, free courses offered through Methodist University to employees, ways to be involved with current projects, a way to share ideas with management and above, and much more.  What really stands out is the culture, from day one I felt immediately welcomed into the Methodist family!  Methodist puts employees first and takes time to make sure you feel valued.

review_title: methodist family health centers physician review
pros: In the outpatient clinics, if you're  busy, you can make a lot of money compared to the same job outside of the hospital system.   They have health and dental benefits, 401K and matching as well as life insurance.  It's an admired health care system with loyal patients. There are many locations to practice from. They have EPIC emr which is fabulous for the patients. You have freedom to practice the way you choose, but there are metrics which are strongly suggested and tied to bonuses you can earn based on patient satisfaction and outcomes.
cons:
If your clinic isn't busy enough, you won't make very much after your guarantee is over. It could be due to the restructuring or change in leadership, but, some doctors are making great pay ($200K +) and some are barely making it ($125-150K+).  My advice - be aggressive with pursuing the salary you desire.

Keep in mind that you really can't control your costs since the clinics are run by Methodist  There are a plethora of costs that eat into your profit margin (fees for referral department, billing fees are mandatory fixed costs, facility and maintenance fees). 

if you can't control your costs, then you can't make as much money. Methodist management's answers to low pay - see more patients, work harder, extend your hours which may or may not be feasible to your particular needs.

Health insurance has  3 options with the most expensive being the one that grants out of network availability. However, the price for insurance and copays is going up ($40 for pcp in network, $60 for out of network $80 to see a specialist) and premiums are on the higher end since Methodist is self-insured.  If your spouse has access to insurance in their job  it will likely be a better option.

pros: There is so much room for growth in this company. I started as a scribe then went to medical assistant and now just graduated the methodist nursing program at el centro. They have helped me every step of the way from clinicals to my work hours at the medhealth clinics. I wouldn't be anywhere else

pros: lots of exposure for those starting out in the medical industry, some of the co-workers are supportive and team focused. Opportunity for improvement and to use many skills if you can breach the cultural climate.
cons:
Management can be patronizing, racist, classist, conservative Republican and intolerant, many co-workers are toxic, hostile, and passive aggressive.  Benefits are the industry standard and not as exceptional as told to candidates excluding the401K plan as any other company.  No training provided, unclear expectations, high turnover rate ( my position was previously filled by four other employees whom mysteriously left and or was fired. While working there two other people vanished for reasons unknown). If you don't pretend to be Republican, wealthy ( from the right family) and a football enthusiast you are shunned and setup to fail. Management will welcome you with open arms then listen to other employees who are in self-protection mode because of the cutthroat climate and will throw you under the bus. Communication, project planning, and task assignment was the most unorganized confusing place I have ever worked. I am completing my third degree, and I have successfully met all of these challenges despite many issues yet this organization was insurmountable with hostility and toxicity making even the most competent candidate feel ostracized.
As a new employee patronizing was the norm for standard and general inquiry a new employee makes when transitioning. Expectations were set for a task that had not been performed before or had significant changes in procedure that management remain unaware of and indifferent to how this impacted performance.  There was no set performance evaluation ( ever disclosed to me), and all things were decided based on subjective gossip.You believe the management is fair and balanced yet as soon as reasonable problems occur for a new employee their loyalty is intense for tenured employees (some are very committed and concerned for healthy outcomes . While others are over aggressive bullies) to the point of blindness to unhealthy dynamics. 

Working for this company was the worst decision I have ever made.  If you have no self-respect, value one-side relationships, classism, and far right wing conservative views this company is for you if not look elsewhere.  After a few weeks you have no idea who to trust, the honeymoon phase ends, two-faced reports begin to take place and subtle yet undeniable hostility starts to show from management.
